article.title: Successive Homologous Coronal Mass Ejections driven by shearing and converging motions in solar active region NOAA 12371

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main pattern observed in the evolution of the magnetic polarities in AR 12371 over the four days shown?
choices: Expansion of the leading polarity and disintegration of the following polarity.
Merging of the positive and negative polarities.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the dark regions (indicated by arrows) observed in the AIA 193 Å images in the last column?
choices: They represent regions of increased magnetic field strength.
They are sunspots associated with the active region.
They indicate areas of EUV dimming, likely footprints of the erupting flux rope.
They are artifacts from the image processing.

multiple_choice_question.text: What eruption mechanism is supported by the observations shown in Figure 3, particularly the AIA 94 Å snapshots?
choices: Ideal MHD kink instability of a pre-existing flux rope.
Breakout reconnection of an overlying field with a low-lying core field.
Internal tether-cutting reconnection within a sheared core field.
Flux cancellation between opposite polarity elements.

multiple_choice_question.text: What key difference in the magnetic parameter evolution is observed between AR 12371 (Figure 7) and the non-eruptive AR 12192 (Figure 9)?
choices: AR 12371 shows a much higher rate of energy flux injection (dE/dt).
AR 12371 exhibits a significantly larger accumulation of normalized coronal helicity (H(t)/Φ²(t)).
AR 12192 has a much stronger and more persistent negative helicity flux injection (dH/dt).
AR 12192 shows a much faster decrease in net magnetic flux, indicating rapid flux cancellation.
